author: Europa Press
title: Empatía, humildad y disponibilidad, las características que más valoran las personas con discapacidad en un jefe
text:
MADRID, 2 Ene. (EUROPA PRESS) -
 Seis de cada diez personas con discapacidad sigue sintiendo discriminación a la hora de competir en el mercado laboral y todos reclaman un empleo estable, flexible, inclusivo y con propósito para que sea verdaderamente sostenible en el tiempo, como se desprende del 4º Informe Discapacidad y expectativas para este 2024 llevado a cabo por Fundación Adecco, para el que se han entrevistado a 300 personas con diferentes capacidades.
 Según se desprende del informe, aún existen sesgos y creencias obsoletas que asocian a los profesionales con discapacidad con menor rendimiento o adaptabilidad, mermando con ello sus oportunidades profesionales".
 Asimismo, las personas con discapacidad "están cambiando la narrativa en el mundo laboral y ya no solo desean un empleo, sino que demandan una inclusión real y duradera, buscan oportunidades verdaderamente inclusivas", ha comentado el director general de la Fundación Adecco, Francisco Mesonero.
 Así, el 85% de las personas con discapacidad que trabajan desean conservar su empleo y un 15% encontrar uno mejor; mientras que los que no están ocupados esperan que 2024 sea el año de su inclusión laboral. Y, 39% de los encuestados menciona la remuneración como una de las principales variables a tener en cuenta en el empleo, seguidos de un 20% que alude a la seguridad, aspirando a un trabajo cómodo y ergonómico, en el que su discapacidad no sea un hándicap a la hora de afrontar situaciones imprevistas.
EL JEFE IDEAL La encuesta también pide opinión sobre las cualidades que debería tener un jefe ideal y para la mayoría (93%) la empatía es la característica principal, seguida del sentido de la justicia (89,3%), la humildad (78,7%), la disponibilidad (66%); la resiliencia (52,3), que resulte inspirador (30,4%) y con capacidad de delegar (30%).
 "El liderazgo inclusivo es una de las grandes palancas para que la inclusión laboral de las personas con discapacidad sea sostenible en el tiempo, pero no solo los managers desempeñan un papel fundamental en este proceso, sino que es necesario que todas las personas de la organización desarrollen la habilidad de incluir, identificando y aceptando sus propios sesgos y generando comportamientos inclusivos que reviertan en entornos más abiertos a la diversidad", ha explicado Mesonero.
 Algunos de los encuestados consideran incluso que algunas celebridades como la cantante Aitana, El Langui o el exfutbolista Joaquín serían para ellos su jefe ideal. Según los encuestados, las celebridades mencionadas atesoran cualidades como el sentido del humor y la sensibilidad (Joaquín), la empatía y resiliencia (El Langui) o el trabajo y la inspiración (Aitana). "Estos atributos dan pie a que las personas con discapacidad les identifiquen como jefes ideales", destaca Begoña Bravo, responsable del Área de Inclusión de la Fundación Adecco.
 En su informe, la organización también expone algunas de las claves para favorecer la integración en las empresas y centros de trabajo como tomar conciencia sobre la diversidad como alto inherente al ser humano y de que no hay dos personas iguales. Otra de las claves, para Fundación Adecco, es reconocer que todas las personas tienen capacidad para mejorar el mundo y es importante descubrir cómo.
 Asimismo, se considera importante luchar contra los sesgos inconscientes que son "un efecto psicológico involuntario que produce una desviación o distorsión del análisis de la realidad. Asimismo, se recomienda identificar los valores para ser una persona más inclusiva como la empatía, la colaboración o el servicio a los demás. Finalmente, se propone ejercitar esos valores y buscar oportunidades para adoptar comportamientos inclusivos.

author: VNExplorer
title: The pacifist politician hoping to change Russia
text: 'We do not want people to think about leaving the country,' Yekaterina Duntsova says Her bid to run against Russian President Vladimir Putin in a March election was rejected and she has since been branded a "foreign agent". But the journalist and former local deputy Yekaterina Duntsova is defiant, saying she still intends to "change" Russia by developing a pacifist opposition movement. Even though almost all Russian opposition figures are either living in exile or in prison, the 41-year-old is hoping to play a role in the political world. "I tell myself: who else if not me?" she told AFP in an interview. Duntsova, a mother of three, was completely unknown in November 2023 when she announced she wanted to run for president with the slogan: "Let's give our country back its future!" She wants a peace deal with Ukraine, the liberation of political prisoners, reforms of the executive power and the judicial system, and the abolition of repressive laws passed to silence any public opposition. She saw her presidential bid rejected by Russian election officials over supposed "errors" in the paperwork. The experience has not put her off. "Ordinary people have followed me, people who feel there could be an alternative, a hope," she said, adding that she had received "hundreds of messages of support" on social media. "For all these people, it was important to know that there were many of them because until then they thought they were alone," Duntsova said. In December 2023, she announced plans to launch a political party "to preserve this community". In January, her supporters chose to name the party "Rassvet" (Dawn) -- a name that she said is "positive, pacifying and giving hope". - 'I am no longer afraid' - On May 1, the party held its first congress in Golitsyno in the Moscow region, with 148 people from 50 Russian regions taking part. One month later, Russia's justice ministry put Duntsova on a list of "foreign agents" -- a method used to silence dissident voices in Russia. Russian law bans "foreign agents" from running for any kind of election or taking part in election campaigns. But Duntsova is not giving up. "I am no longer afraid," she said. "Under the law, a political party as a whole cannot be considered a foreign agent. The majority of our supporters have stayed with us. We will continue!" Among her supporters are many young people like Vladislav Fomin, a 22-year-old student. "I'm not afraid. When you really love your country, you should not stop at the obstacles the authorities put in your way. Even with these restrictions, we keep working," he said. Another activist from Rassvet, Ivan Polushin, a 19-year-old student, said he was happy he had found "people with similar political convictions". - 'Patriotism is love and prosperity' - Duntsova said she hoped that Rassvet "will continue to develop civil society" in Russia and raise awareness among compatriots who think only of "home, work and seaside holidays". No change is possible "if people do not take part in elections" as candidates or voters, she said. Her own story is one of political awakening. After growing up in the small town of Rzhev around 200 kilometres (125 miles) west of Moscow, she worked for 17 years as a journalist in a local television station founded by her husband. The station was forced to close in 2022, she said, without giving details. She got into local politics and was elected to the local council in 2019, serving until 2022. She worked on numerous environmental projects while in office. "We do not want people to think about leaving the country. We want them to build homes, to work, to have children if they want. "For us, patriotism is love and prosperity and not sacrifice like the state wants," Duntsova said. bur/spb

author: Kim Roberts
title:
Presbyterian Church in America Removes Webpage, Apologizes 
The conservative denomination apologized for linking to advice about how immigrants can avoid being detained.
text:
The domestic mission agency of the Presbyterian Church in America has removed a webpage containing links to advice about how illegal immigrants can avoid being detained by law enforcement authorities.
The archived webpage published on January 9 by Mission to North America (MNA) started by framing the issue with a question, “Did you know? The average undocumented person has been present in the US for more than a decade.”
It went on to provide links to “reliable secular sources” that “may be useful to you as you seek to love your immigrant neighbor well.”
In a statement published on byFaith ’s website, the PCA apologized.
“MNA’s leadership erroneously allowed the posting of content that advised undocumented persons on ways to avoid being detained by authorities. We affirm that it is our Christian duty to obey the lawful commands of the civil magistrate and be subject to their authority (WCF 23.4; Romans 13:1-4; 1 Peter 2:13-14). To counsel otherwise is a sin…We repent and apologize.”
The apology acknowledged the action had fallen short of the “Biblical and Confessional standard” and had caused “confusion and consternation” in the PCA.
It also acknowledged that MNA should not engage in providing legal advice or engaging in political campaigns.
“The information we post going forward will provide ecclesiastical resources in line with our Confession for guidance on the matter,” the statement said. The PCA holds the Westminster Confession of Faith as its denominational doctrinal standard.
The MNA permanent committee has a meeting scheduled for the first week of March and is planning to discuss this issue in more detail “as part of the Committee’s regular oversight of MNA’s ministries.”
Mission to North America is focused on church planting throughout the U.S. and Canada and also promotes church vitality by providing ministry resources that “enable churches to grow in their outward-facing missional engagement.
The Refugee and Immigrant Ministry is part of the church vitality prong of MNA’s mission.
